title: Lituya Glacier
text:
Lituya Glacier is a tidewater <a href="glacier">glacier</a> in the <a href="U.S.%20state">U.S. state</a> of <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a>. Located at inside <a href="Glacier%20Bay%20National%20Park%20and%20Preserve">Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve</a>, its source is in the <a href="Fairweather%20Range">Fairweather Range</a> and it feeds into <a href="Lituya%20Bay">Lituya Bay</a> on the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Alaska">gulf</a> coast of <a href="Alaska%20Panhandle">Southeast Alaska</a>.
It is partially responsible for creating the <a href="1958%20Lituya%20Bay%20megatsunami">1958 Lituya Bay megatsunami</a>. The glacier, which has receded over the years, carved Lituya Bay into a unique topographic phenomenon with steep walls, a very deep submerged bottom, and a very narrow entrance to the ocean which created the opportunity for a megatsunami to occur.
The glacier is also the namesake of the <a href="Alaska%20Marine%20Highway">Alaska Marine Highway</a> ferry <a href="M/V%20Lituya">M/V "Lituya"</a>.
